Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Understanding Steroid Regulation of Ionotropic Glutamate Receptors

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
There are many mechanisms by which communication between neurons is regulated. Glutamate, the major fast excitatory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system, has, as one of its prime targets, the ionotropic glutamate receptors (iGluRs) which reside in the postsynaptic neural membrane. Ionotropic glutamate receptors are a family of ligand gated ion channels, which include AMPA, kainate, and NMDA receptors. Upon binding to glutamate, the opening of a nonselective cation channel allows an influx of positive charge, leading to postsynaptic cell depolarization, and hence propagation of the action potential. These receptors are carefully regulated. The endogenous sulfated steroids, pregnenolone sulfate and pregnenolone sulfate, which are structurally very similar, have been shown to differentially regulate these receptors. Previous research from the Gentile lab has shown that these steroids bind to one of two extracellular domains, dependant upon the iGluR family member. Using this as a platform, a combination of high resolution structural studies, computational studies, and mutational analysis will now allow for an understanding of this regulation on a detailed molecular level. The goal is to understand which binding events and conformational changes lead to an opening of the iGluR channel (and propagation of the action potential) and which lead to its closing.

Broader Impacts
The broader impacts of this project are focused both on exciting and training the next generation of students in the process of scientific discovery. This research will provide high quality, outcome-oriented, interdisciplinary training to undergraduates at the University of Richmond (UR). In addition, it will involve high school chemistry and biology teachers in Richmond, VA in an inquiry based investigation, which will enable them to develop new techniques ranging in scope from biophysics to molecular biology, gather ideas to incorporate into new courses or labs, earn professional development points, and introduce them to UR faculty that can serve as future mentors. It will also involve high school students in summer research, which will allow them to develop critical thinking and problem solving skills, as well as to expose them to the excitement of science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project had both a scientific goal- to understand the impact of ligands on the structure and flexibility of the ligand binding domains of ionotropic glutamate receptors- and a broader impact goal- to provide training of both undergraduates and high school students and their teachers, particularly under-represented minority students in an environment that would stimulate their interests in science and careers in science.

 

Ionotropic Glutamate receptors are multisubunit proteins responsible for the majority of fast excitatory synaptic transmission in the brain and are comprised of two major families of proteins, the NMDA and Non-NMDA (mainly the so-called AMPA)  types of receptors

 

These receptors control the  activity-dependent synaptic plasticity that is the basis of learning and memory formation. The  AMPA family of receptors are also thought to contribute to  excitotoxic cell death in diseases such as epilepsy, hypoxic ischemia, and other neurodegenerative diseases as well as act in normal regulation of sleep and respiration. The root of  these chronic and acute neurological diseases is believed to be overactivity of the ionotropic glutamate channels and compounds that act as negative modulators of their activity are potential candidates for future development of new drugs to treat ionotropic glutamate receptor associated diseases.

 

Two steroids, 3-a-Hydroxy-5b- pregnan-20-one sulfate (PregaS), and pregnenolone sulfate (PS) which differs from PregaS by only one double bond in the steroid ring juncture  have been shown to inhibit NMDA receptors in a noncompetitive manner (PregaS) or Non-NMDA receptors (PS) as at least a partial inhibitor. Interestingly PS potentiates the NMDA receptor response to glutamate.

 

The basic structures of both types of receptor have been established in recent years and show many similarities in the receptor  domain and transmembrane channel regions but differ in the intracellular regions of the protein. While prior work has established that multiple conformational states of the proteins play roles in the mechanism of ion channel opening little is known about the dynamic nature of the proteins and the response to either stimulatory or inhibitory signals.

 

The scientific goals of the current project were to establish the nature of the steroids binding sites on the proteins and determine the effects of stimulatory ligands (Glutamte) or the  inhibitory neurosteroids , PregaS and PS on the conformation and dynamic properties of both an NMDA type receptor and a Non-NMDA type receptor- in this case an AMPA receptor. Since we wanted to examine the interplay between stimulatory (ie Glutamate) and inhibitory (ie steroid) effects we  developed  a fluorescence based approach using multiple types of quenchers of tryptophan fluorescence that had the ability to dissect the contributions of individual tryptophans in the proteins. Using this approach we have shown that the stimulatory ligand, glutamate, had different effects on the flexibility of either type of receptor (enhancing the flexibility of NMDA receptors that could be activated by PS but decreasing the flexibility of either family of receptors that could be inhibited by both PregaS and PS) while the steroids have different effects depending upon receptor type: PS greatly decreased the flexibility of all receptor ligand binding domains shown to bind steroids while PregaS had little  effect on flexibility but did significantly change the local charge environment of the ligand binding domains of responsive AMPA or NMDA receptors.
